This project is a 3D snowman wearing a hat. It was designed using tinkercad for 3D printing.
NGSS CCSS

To accomplish this project I used tinkercad, which is a program used for designing 3D objects. I faced some issues while using this program, for it was the first time for me to design a 3D object on this program, and it took me time to get used to it. However, it is a great program for beginners like me. These are the steps I followed to design this object:
First I inserted 3 spheres for the snowman's body. Starting from the biggest sphere(bottom) to the smallest sphere(top). Next, I used a cone to make the nose. Then, I used small spheres for the eyes, mouth, and the buttons on his "shirt". After that, I used thin cylinders to make the hands.
Finally, I used a flat sphere and a cylinder to make his hat. You can resize, re color, and add anything to make your own unique snowman!
Tinkercad + desktop

author: Halfnuts

description.text:
I heavily tweaked Seadevil's awesome design to move the switch to the other side of the cover as I have my PSU vertically mounted in a specific direction. Overall this design uses less plastic, less space and provides more internal space for wiring.

Here are the main changes:

  • Increased the front hole to be much wider and go across the whole cover to facilitate wiring and voltage adjustments.
  • Removed the waves as it was unnecessarily complicating the print and have no structural issues.
  • Increased internal space by about 3mm in height to accommodate the switch mounting holes.
  • Changed the Wire holes cover to allow for later installation without rewiring anything.
  • Rotated the switch 180 degrees so you can more easily grip the side and flip the switch on and off.
  • Copied the right side vent holes to the left to make the design cleaner.

I apologize for any onscreen design artifacts, I did this completely in tinkercad so its not perfectly precise but pretty close. It prints perfectly without any of the onscreen artifacts.

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

title: Autonomous Drone Frame (Raspberry Pi + Naze32 FC)

description.text:
BEWARE: Frame may be too heavy with current setup / no lightening holes!

This is the base of the Android Autonomous Drone project I'm working on, which you can find the details of on my site or my Medium blog.

The arms used are not my design, but the ZMR 250 replacement arms for 2204 motors you can find here.

The powertrain consists of 4 EMAX MT2204-2300KV outrunners paired with I believe 20A ESCs (the labels peeled off soon after purchase), drawing power from a 3S 1300mAh Lipo.

The mounting points are designed for a Raspberry Pi 3 and a Naze32 flight controller. As a disclaimer the LiPo does not have fixing points in the frame, though is a snug fit under the Pi plate. I imagine I'll be using foam blocks attached with double sided tape to allow for different battery sizes and positioning.

The hardware you'll need are as follows:

  • 16x counter-sunk M3 x 12mm
  • 4x round head M3 x 8mm
  • 4x mounting screws for the PI (M2 x 6mm)
  • 4x mounting screws for the Naze32 FC (M3 x 10mm)
  • 4x 2mm nuts for M3 screws

Nuka Cola bottle cord stop.

Spring and plunger from the DRITZ 1-1/4" cord stop (available in black, white, and translucent). Use pliers to squeeze​ the outer casing on the solid sides of the DRITZ stop while pulling the plunger, should come right out (don't lose the spring!).

Change log:

Version 2 (4/23/2017):

  • Increased size by ~5%, no need to modify the DRITZ plunger now.
  • Now available with a bottle cap. The fine detail on the model barely shows up on a 0.5mm nozzle printer, still, it gives you some clear delineations to paint. I haven't tried a resin print of it, I doubt it would be strong enough for real use. Maybe a 0.35mm printer will do better.

If you're printing v1 for some reason, sand down the tabs on the side of the plungers to about half their original height (an emery board works well), insert spring and plunger into bottle, and use considerable force to push it in. Once it latches you're not taking the plunger out again unless you break the bottle in half to do it.

title: Mitre Box for 2020 Aluminium T-slot Extrusion

description.text:
Mitre box for Aluminium 2020 T-Slot extrusion, or anything else less than 20x20mm. Central slots (inc. 45 degree slots) are 1mm wide which is good for a standard large hacksaw blade, with 0.8mm and 0.7mm slots to either side for thinner hacksaw blades. 1mm slots tested and work well - very little play, but also don't bind.

All slots continue 1mm into the base to avoid damage to the box when you cut through the extrusion.

Recess is 21mm wide to allow a small tolerance for printer settings etc. 30mm recess depth allows for the saw to be aligned in the box to make the initial cut. Chamfered top edges of slots for ease.

Designed for my Hypercube build so I didn't have to order a mitre box just for that. If you haven't checked out Tech2C's amazing Hypercube, do it now! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752766

.f3d file included - feel free to edit.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.250 is fine

Infill:

15-20% with 3 perimiters

Notes:

Printed fine on Anet A8 (Prusa clone). Avoid ABS given large flat base (even with heated bed). PET-G worked great - super strong but not as brittle as PLA. No warping issues at 60 degrees on the bed straight onto blue painters tape.

The glossy black PET-G shows up every tiny detail, so despite the sloppy appearance in the pics, the part is smooth with no flaws. with 105% flow rate I got 20.55mm recess width - nice snug fit.

remixed_from.title: MadBull XM-PB4 grenade modified lower body

description.text:
https://youtu.be/gHFR2Y0xiaI

NEW: I have added a pusher to put the balls at the bottom of the barrels.

I had a gas grenade that worked very badly for airsoft. I decided to recycle it in hand grenade. I retrieve the tube and piston system from my old grenade. I put the tube at the bottom of the front part and the piston in the back part. For the pin I took an alluminium part (see photo) I made a 4mm hole well placed to fill the gas. Then I re-drilled the barrel with the drill (6mm).

To recharge it is necessary to push the piston just enough so that the pin passes. Then the 6 cannons must be filled with balls (they must enter without forcing). Reaching 4 by canon is a good compromise to keep the range. Then pull the pin to release the piston. It works very well for me. Be careful when pulling the pin the piston part is violently avoiding to take it. May also add a torque joint to prevent the plunger from tapping too hard against the bottom.
ps: If the Screw thread passes poorly the first time to oil a little and to go slowly it will work better after.

title: Arkham Horror Fancy Three Card Holder

description.text:
I have Arkham Horror and as everyone who owns the game knows there are a lot of items and cards. This is the beginning of my attempt to organize all of the items so that the setup of the game is reduced.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/h424VhEX1Us

Thanks to guru for his Volumetric Tentacle
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6650

Arkham Horror Fancy Large Two Card Holder

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2281929

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

A skirt may be needed if you use ABS or do not have a heated bed to prevent warping.

Design considerations

In the basic game there are 9 sets of mini cards (63.5mm x 40.8mm x 0.35mm) of varying amounts. So 3 sets of 3 should be a very manageable grouping for the cards.

I built a basic box with inserts to divide the cards.

The walls and bottom are 2mm; the dividers are 1.2mm. These thicknesses should be optimal for a 0.4mm print nozzle.

I also own Dunwich Horror and a few expansions, so the height of the tallest deck(Spells 34mm) + 2mm(base) + 1mm(Buffer) = 37mm box height.

I wanted to evoke the game by added tentacles warping around the box.

description.text:
My son wanted a fidget spinner. I thought it is a waste to use bearings as weights. So I found a design here on Thingverse that uses quarters as weights. Except it printed the bearing hole too small and the quarter holes too big. Maybe just differences in printer resolutions/accuracy. So I remixed by making the bearing hole sllightly bigger and reshaped the quarter holes so that the quarters would be captured inside of the hole.

Designed for 2 quarters in each hole making my cost $2.20 ( 6 quarters, 1 bearing, plastic)

THIS REQUIRES THAT YOU PAUSE THE PRINTER AT ABOUT 60% TO DROP THE QUARTERS IN.

Turns out the bearings cost about 50 cents each, and since I have two quarters in each hole, it is a push. Well.....I have more quarters sitting around than bearings.

Link to bearings that I used https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C9XDPVQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Link to Quarters that I used
https://www.usmint.gov/

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:
  • used ABS
  • at about 60% complete you need to pause the printing and drop the quarters in
  • use 2 quarters per coin hole
  • make sure you have the sides of the coins showing that you want
  • CAUTION - the quarters hold the heat from the bed alot longer than the plastic

description.text:
Probably only people from germany will know this brand and have their glass botles.
I have designed special bottle mounts that can be attached to walls or vertical surfaces (like shelves) and will hold these glass bottles.

There are two party for each small and big bottles:
The top holder jams the bottle threads, so it can not slip out.
The bottom part is only needed if you want to attach a bottle to a shelf.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

How to use:

Although this model is designed with 0,2mm gap, both parts might slightly stick together, so you will have to cut throug the sticked parts to separate them. Be careful!

After that, you can bend the mount just wide enough to put it around the bottleneck with the thread.

Designed with Tinkercad

https://tinkercad.com/things/7PSlFUVFLUF

This is a clip for mounting a tail light onto a bike rack. I used it to mount a "Portland Design Works" Danger Zone tail light to my "Topeak" Super Tourist DX bike rack. This design will hold many different tail lights as this clip design seems to be standard among some manufactures. I have tested it with a very cheep Chinese light and it works well for that as well as my Danger Zone light. It should also also work with "Planet Bike" lights. The rack mount holes on this clip are 50mm apart. I have included a base clip that can be adjusted in Sketchup as needed for different designs. This is not a useful design in itself, its just for building other sizes as needed. This is more or less a copy of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8947. I don't know OpenSCAD so I redesigned it from scratch in Sketchup. The above rack mount clip works great but the bolt holes at 81.5mm were two far apart. if you need a bigger clip or want an OpenSCAD file for this clip try the above link If you need a single hole mount You might find http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25621 helpful, but I found the design good but the measurements to be way out of whack and measuring in meters not millimeters.
I printed this with ABS to give the flexibility and strength. I would not recommend PLA as the clip needs to flex and the mount would not hold up in the elements on the back of a bike as well.

description.text:
Based upon daveyclk's design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1762299) this cuts out all the parts that to me seemed to be unnecessary and make it print faster, easier and cheaper. It is supposed to be mounted and you need something to cover up the turntable.
Note: I will update the files to include a way to connect the main plate part to the pole by means of a bolt and nut

Currently I have a slightly bulkier version of this setup. After printing most of the parts I noticed areas that could be slimmed down further. Added photos (added later!) will thus look slightly different from the 3D models.

Huge thanks to Dave for the original design (the cog and knob are pretty much modifications of his) and the community who made the split up turntable.

All parts were designed with minimal infill required. For instance my cog differs that all horizontal areas are sloped down.

The opening in the base is made for the headphones that came with my LG G5. It has 2 holes underneath for screws to adjust the height if needed.

Designed in Sketchup, printed on an Anet A8

description.text:
This is a spinner based on a mustache! Takes any skateboard bearing and uses 2x 5/16 nuts. Mine came from lowes(part #63302).

I printed with 5% infill and seems to be perfect. I've been printing at .3mm layer height and 40 speed as this doesn't require detail.
Size is exact as in not over-sized, so may require a vise to get the nuts in. If you have issues scale up by 1-3%.

If you print these please tag me on social media using either @whoishack(instagram and twitter) as well as #improperengineering

remixed_from.title: B+ Pi Cam Ultimaker 2 timelapse harness

title: Timelapse harness head for Raspberry Pi Camera Module v2.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
nigeljohnson73 made a great timelapse harness, but it only worked with the Raspberry Pi Camera Module version 1. So I decided to fiddle and develop a slightly modified version of the original camera head ("pi_cam_head_v2.stl") which had a few issues:

1) Four posts weren't big enough to hold the new v2.1 camera module.

2) Opening for the camera, and the space for the electronics/connector, wasn't large enough.

3) There wasn't a lot of clearance for the bolt and the camera at the same time, so I added a few mm so the awesome knurled bolt heads don't destroy your camera. (You're welcome!)

I printed a blue one (shown), and am printing a white one now for production use.

I think the next item I'll design is the support piece/hook ("hook_front_v2.stl") so that it works with the FlashForge Creator Pro (2016 edition). Then I'll be back in business video-wise!

(When I say "fiddle and develop" in the first paragraph, what I mean is, I printed his version, held the v2.1 camera module up to the original, and used digital calipers to figure out where things needed to be. I then build a brand new model in Fusion 360, from scratch.)

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Reverse Engineering and Fusion 360

This is my first remix using reverse engineering, rather than the original STL file. I'm not really that good with meshes and editing of meshes, but I can use digital calipers and plug numbers into Fusion 360. Overall a fun project, and I ended up with a working piece or two, for the excellent timelapse harness designed by nigeljohnson73!

3D model taken from http://roestudios.co.uk/project/3d-pokemon-models and edited with Meshmixer/Blender for desired result. Feel free to remix.

- Updated: The clamp bar piece to have a slightly taller phone grip. Also fixed a minor gap causing a slight cosmetic issue with the first model.** - Update2: the 4mm Hex head screw should be 4x10mm not 12..
- Update3: Added a 7.5" version of the phone clamp piece to allow for vertical mounting of some phones like the Samsung Galaxy series. This is a phone clamp for the iControlPad Bluetooth game controller (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IControlPad), This is a replacement for the original universal phone clamp which was comprised of a bent piece of metal with holes at approximate phone widths and a cheap single use plastic rivet to fasten it in place. the biggest flaw of using a plastic rivet in the official phone clamp is once the pin was in, the only way to take it off was to take apart the controller and push the pin out from the inside. which made using it as a stand alone controller kind of annoying. My design allows easy removal of the clamp as it just slides off when the tightener is loosened and you can just leave the tightener on the controller. It is much more adjustable for larger phones like the Samsung Galaxy S3/4 and possible the Notes series. You will need to open the case of icontrolpad once to fasten down the "screw based adapter" piece. On top of the three pieces you will need to print, the following will be needed to fasten the clamp to the controller all can be found at most hardware stores. I highly recommend stainless steel for the screws and nuts.
  • 3x10mm Flat Head Machine Screw.
  • 3mm Hex Nut.
  • 4x10mm Hex head screw for the tightener
  • 4mm Hex Nut.
  • Optional super/crazy glue for tightener and the 4x10mm hex screw (if needed depending on tolerances of the 3D Print).

The pieces were designed by myself using Tinkercad. Printed with a Printrbot Jr V2 with Aluminium heated bed using PLA @ 200C and bed at 70C. You will need these fasteners:
  • 3x10mm Flat Head Machine Screw.
  • 3mm Hex Nut.
  • 4x10mm Hex head screw for the tightener
  • 4mm Hex Nut.
  • Optional super/crazy glue for tightener and the 4x10mm hex screw (if needed depending on tolerances of the 3D Print).
    • Assembly is fairly simple:
    1.) You will need to open the iControlpad. Take off rubber sides, and remove the 4 screws in the back. Leave the iCP face down and lift up the back piece.
    2.) Place the 4mm hex nut into the screw base adapter. This may be slightly loose, however it won't move when attached to the case.
    3.) Attach the screw based adapter to the back of the iControlpad it should click in place with the existing square hole, use the 3mm flat-head screw and nut and fasten. (should be snug, not overtightened) You can now put the iControlpad back together.
    4.) Slide the 4mm Hex nut into the Tightener piece, Depending on tolerance of the print you may or may not need glue here.
    5.) Thread the Tightener piece into the screw base adapter and slide the clamp bar in place. Now it's ready to attach the phone, to the iControlpad. Add a little pressure when clamping to ensure the phone doesn't slide and tighten to keep in place.

description.text:
The Comp108 is an easy to print 108mm micro quadcopter frame designed to run 2.5" props and 2S batteries! Check out this video to see it in action with 7000kv and 7500kv 1104 size motors: https://youtu.be/IFpvkxkisDY

V1.1 Updates - minor changes to hole size to increase margin of error for printing.

This frame was designed with the following goals:

  1. Create a layout which can use a wide variety of components in an effort to increase participation in the MultiGP “Micro” racing class by allowing pilots to use parts they may have on hand.
  2. Develop a design which is functional, durable, and can be printed using a broad range of filaments and by individuals with minimal 3D printing capabilities.
  3. Explore the effects of bevels, chamfers, and infill patterns on the strength of a printed quadcopter frame.

The project resulted in the development of three different versions:

The Basher – This version of the design is based on the original concept drawing dimensions. It can be printed using PLA, and will still have plenty of strength. Of course, the tradeoff is that this is the heaviest version, but it will be tough!

The Racer – This version was created to see how thin and light we could make the arms and overall frame. After experimenting with materials we recommend that you print with more exotic filaments such as nylon, and even then be aware that you are trading durability for light weight and low drag.

The Cruiser – This version is a middle ground between the Basher and the Racer. While PLA will work for this version, you will gain durability if you print in ABS or PETG.

Notes:

  • The Comp108 frames can use flight controllers with either 30.5mm or 20mm hole spacing, 4-in-1 ESCs of both sizes or smaller individual ESCs, and 1103-1106 size motors (use 6mm bolts for motor mounting).
  • We have designed a range of camera mounts, if you don't seem something that meets your needs feel free to be creative! Remember that the outside holes will line up with a full size flight controller mounting pattern, so you can use one of the many already available camera mounts, or use one of the flight controller stack plates as the base of your own design.
  • The models should be printed logo side down for best results, and it is recommended that you take the time to orient your infill to align with the arms to increase overall strength (see picture for example).
  • Experiment with materials, settings, and remember to have fun!

Top plates and camera mount designs can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/HalfAshby/designs

Also, check out Max's design for a camera mounting solution here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2561423

description.text:
aye odd title for design I know but bare with me and you'll start to understand.

This design is more of a set of designs, the designed parts contained within can be used in Multiple configurations and can incorporate the use of stock ZMR 250 frame parts if the builder so wishes (or not if they choose, its entirely down to their own tastes, desires or needs.

included designs are

alternative full 3d printed ZMR arms (with Esc cavity and built in LED's)
lower sandwich plate spacer with rear led board mount(for stock 3mm ZMR arms)
upper plate (battery slot, alarm/vtx mount, protective shroud for cam antenna)
lower plate with skid feet.

the designs are made in such a way as to match the dimensions and hole layout of stock ZMR 250 frame plates so the builder can use the stock plates for additional strength (I currently fly the FULL 3d printed version of this design and find it remarkably strong tbh but the choice is yours), this also allows for the optional use of the upgraded PDB type ZMR plates too.

Though I have dispensed with the use of the upper stock plate in my own builds (giving the whole frame a more low slung streamline appearance) the plate is still usable if you wish (though imho the whole thing will look top heavy if used with the spacer parts)

The cam Ill be using and the parts are designed around is a Eachine AIO tx03 but they should work fine with sinilar AIO types (including the tx02 and 01 obviously), however if the builder chooses to use one of the stock ZMR plates a slot must be cut into it to allow for the antenna.

well I could sit here explaining all the different variants you could use but you can probably figure the rest out for yourselves.

the built version Im using as is shown above in the pictures is as I said the entire 3d printed version without using zmr stock parts, its entirely ABS and very tough and rigid.

to minimise height requirement of the spacer I designed it primarily around the use of a CC3d v2.0 which had a built in PDB with 12v & 5v regs (it can also be directly powered from anything upto 6s lipo in cell amount), however you can fit any 30x30 FC (Naze, f4 etc) inside with upto a 30x30 PDB even with your receiver and cam still in there, you just have to be more careful with your wire management.

Ive shoved in a pic of a handful of possible variants above to give some general ideas of what possible, enjoy and feel free to comment or suggest further mods.

ooops forgot to mention...
the leds I designed for and will be using are these:-
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/142067571176?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=441163776462&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

22/4/2017:-added

stock arm esc covers
snapshots of build variants

24/4/2017:-added

LED mounts for 5mm leds (alternative to using neopixel smd leds)

for ease of install Id recommend "pre-wired" LEDs, Ive used the following seller for multiple projects and his pre-wired LEDS are reliable, REALLY "ultra-bright" at 12v but still bright at 5v (without needing to change the resistor pre-installed).

they have many varying colours and function pre-wired 5mm leds that are usable (such as flashing & flicker) aswell as flat-top version LED's

http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/5-x-Pre-Wired-White-LED-5mm-Ultra-Bright-9V-12V-1st-CLASS-POST-/301164692846?hash=item461ed0856e

http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/5-x-Pre-Wired-Red-LED-5mm-Ultra-Bright-9V-12V-1st-CLASS-POST-/301164692609?hash=item461ed08481

text6_size = 5.5

The Replicator's feed tubes lie along the back of the Replicator, but the filament feeds from spools that stick out from the back, especially the left extruder spool which is pushed out 20 mm. So the filament can bind getting pulled across the spool, or even occasionally wrap between the spool and the Replicator. This support bends the feed tubes out so that they're centered over the spools, causing them to feed more smoothly.

Make sure that the Replicator's feed tubes have a few inches of loose tube below the clips. If yours is not like this, you may need to unclip the clips and reclip them to the tube.
Print. 10% fill, one shell, is fine.
Move it 200mm in the Y axis (i.e. from the build platform to the back of the Replicator).
Slide the support under the three cables on the back of the replicator, and position it so that the left extruder's feed tube slides into the shorter slot, and the right extruder's feed tube slides into the longer slot, and the black cable runs through the middle. Rotate it up so that it stands straight out the back of the Replicator. The (black) center cable should move freely, and the two (white) feed tubes will squeeze slightly into the slots. The pressure from the cables will hold it in place against the back of the Replicator.
The attached picture should make everything clear.

remixed_from.author: ericthepoolboy
remixed_from.title: Toyota 4 Cylinder Engine 22RE, Complete working model

description.text:
Update: Added butterfiles for the carburator. You might have to ream out to a 3mm bolt. Print with brim and bed only support.

I designed this as an option for those ofyou that wanted a more race style 22R motor. I included 2 options for the dual carbs.

One option is velocity stacks, and the other option is a K&N style filters.

Depending on the ype of screw you use the filter might have to slightly shaved where the screws are. I used tapered screws that sat flush with the botton filter surface.

The stacks and Clips for the filter were printed at 60% fill everything else was printed at 15%. The intake headers are a redsign of ericthepoolboy's original intake so all the mounting stays the same. Carburators are set up for the linkage assembly.

Big thanks to Ericthepoolboy for creating the motor.

title: MiG 15 - Mikoyan-Gurevich
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you look online nobody has a nice Korean War era MiG 15 to 3D print. The MiG is a classic and unlike modern fighters it has less fiddly parts. I found a detailed plastic model kit to base this on, but I have simplified it down to a more manageable print.

I have supplied the plane in four pieces. The four pieces are small enough a typical 3D printer can do it. It will need a bit of glue. I still want to get the full model down to something around 5 inches that prints nicely...less detail...but more fun with a faster print!
I found a very detailed plastic model kit. Sadly, detailed models make terrible bases for small 3D prints. I use the plastic model as reference, and then used TinkerCAD to make the model.

comments.text: I'm looking at that set up to build my own. Range and speed with it? Which wheels and pulleys? If you have the link I would love it, thanks.
comments.author: Mike50514

comments.text: The range is disappointing. I've been getting around 3 miles at the consistent (max) speed of 20 mph (or around 7 miles with an average speed of 8 mph) . My reduction ratio is ~2.86:1 (I have a 14 tooth motor pulley and a 40 tooth wheel pulley(from SDP/SI)). I also used 83mm wheels from ebay. I would absolutely recommend a different esc (unless you are on a budget) because the acceleration is terribly sudden with the one I used and a compatible programing card is difficult to get. I would also recommend getting higher discharge and mah batteries. A bms is also an almost necessary component. If you intend to use the board in an area that lacks hills, hub motors should be a consideration as the motor mount is the most complicated part of a traditional board. Otherwise a chain and sprocket drive might be a good option. It's loud but rarely, if ever, breaks compared to a 9mm fiberglass belt.

author: brotherchris

description.text:
This is a mounting bracket for attaching a sparkfun accelerometer (part number SEN00252) to a bicycle.  
Why bother mounting an accelerometer to a bike, you ask?  This accelerometer mount is part of a larger project.  The idea is to map out the roughness of various bike paths in the city I live in.  What I want to do is rapidly sample the acceleration generated on the bike frame by the bumps in the bike paths over a few seconds.  I'll then write the peak acceleration to the memory card and tag this data with GPS information so I know where the data was captured.  Once I have completed my bike ride, I'll use Processing (processing.org) to crunch the numbers and generate colour-coded blobs to give me a visual representation of the roughness of the bike path along the route I've taken.  I'll lay this data over a map of the area, and voila!  I will have easy-to-understand information about which paths in the city are in good shape and which ones are to be avoided. (or repaired!)  
Now, the hardware details:
I have an Arduino with a GPS logger shield from Adafruit. (adafruit.com)  This allows me to capture positional data and log it to a text file, along with any other information I'd like to record.  
I have selected a three-axis accelerometer breakout board from Sparkfun. (sparkfun.com) This will allow three-axis acceleration measurement of up to 6g.  
The only thing missing is a sturdy bracket to mount the accelerometer to the bike frame...

comments.text: Very interesting project! I'm in Vitória Brazil and one big problem here is street roughness! That would be interesting to map this!

comments.text: Cool project - merging the roughness data with GPS generated bike routes could probably make the GPS reroute to avoid the worst patches.

title: Mini Spice Cabinet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The cabinet is designed to be cut from a 4mm material such as plywood. The doors can be made from 3mm thick clear or coloured acrylic.  The cabinet measures H108mmW378mmD80mm - designed to fit on a 400mm square sheet. Most of the joints in this design are interlocking, so little glue is required to hold everything together.

To assemble this cabinet you will require:
â€¢ PVA or wood glue
â€¢ Small model making clamps or bulldog (stationery) clamps for clamping small pieces
â€¢ F-clamps or masking tape for holding together final model All parts are numbered inside the design file. Assembly instructions:
  • Slot in + glue top door guides [2+3] into top [1] = [1+2+3]. The raster engraved grooves should be facing up toward the guides
  • Glue bottom lining [7] to bottom [6] on the grooved side = [6+7]. Side and back tab edges should be perfectly aligned.
  • Glue together the back [6+7] and top [1+2+3]. The back piece [6+7] should be facing in the same direction as the door guides [2+3]
  • Slot + glue back top support [5] into back [4].
  • Glue bottom lining front strip [8] to [6+7] on the grooved side. Align with front edge with side edges protruding evenly
  • Glue together back [9] to bottom assembly [6+7+8]. The back piece [9] should be facing in the same direction as the raster engraved grooves and the lining and guide pieces [7+8]
  • You now have the bottom and top parts assembled. Next is attaching these to the sides
  • Slot in and glue top [1+2+3+4+5] and bottom [6+7+8+9] to one of the sides [10]. Works best when the side piece [10] is lying flat, and the other components are insterted into the slots from above
  • Place the other side [10] flat on the working surface and insert the assembly into the slots. This is a tight fit, so you may need a rubber mallet or something heavyish on hand to help with the slotting.
  • Either use the f-clamps to hold everything together while the glue sets, or tightly wrap masking tape around the box
  • Allow at least 12 hours for the glue to dry. Sand off any messy glue globs, prime and paint the cabinet.
  • Once the paint is completely dry, insert the sliding doors.
    • Additional notes:
    The only pieces that have different front and back are the top [1] and the bottom [6] pieces.
    Try assembling the parts first without gluing to make sure youâ€™re comfortable with the assembly.
    The tabs are designed for a tight fit, so perfect alignment is important.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed it on the side, i.e. with the holes vertically.

description.text:
I bought the original floats for the Carbon Cub. But the preowner of my plane glued the gear rod into the fuselage. This points more to the back. Bowing it into the original holder wouldn't work well. So I copied the holder and made it a bit more rugged, as I dön't trust the PLA much.
I don't know how the original part is bullt at the lower part. I put a nose there for better hold. I cut a groove with a hot wire. But be careful, the material is not very thick there. So I put some PU glue into the groove and glued the part with superglue to the top just behind the front holder.
The screw holes are not very strong. Don't use force. I might change the design so that more material is at that area.

Renkforce RF100

I printed it on the side, i.e. with the holes vertically.

My son has a number of the Disney Star Wars Helmets and, since I didn't really want them on the family-room furniture, I needed to build him a shelf. These are designed to fit four helmets each. I had a little bit of curling at the corners, so I'll probably add a corner brace eventually, but that may just be an issue with my printer.

These keychains are for the nerds out there who can't or don't want to decide which is better. Star Wars or Star Trek.

Haven't had a chance yet to see what orientation will work better. Most likely, any orientation will need some supports.

Feel free to mix and match symbols to your liking.

p.s. When I print them out, I'll add photos.

Edit 04/27/17 I fixed the nerd light keychain. When I ran it through Craftware to slice, I did auto supports and found a few places where the supports went through.
I also think that the best way to slice, with the fewest supports, is with the logos facing the front of the bed and on its edge.

05/04/17 May the Fourth be with you. ;)
Added some pictures.

description.text: Most USB motorcycle converters / chargers are difficult to install due to their size (and its often ugly). Hier sind Vorlagen für die Endschalter, und Winkelabdeckungen.
Der Marquardt 1050.0202 Endschalter passt in in die ausgedruckte Vorlage.
Die Endkappen haben oben Löcher, für die Schalter.
Wer gerne Kappen ohne Löcher haben möchte bescheid sagen, aber vielleicht lade ich auch sehr bald einfach welche hoch. Weitere Änderungswünsche wären ebenfalls möglich kann aber keine schnelle Umsetzung garantieren.
Bei Problemen einfach mal wie gezeigt positionieren so hat es bei mir am besten geklappt ;)
Habe nun auch die befestigungen für das Netzteil hochgeladen. Damit kann man das Netzteil von oben fest schrauben.

Habe nun nochmal ein wenig editiert und die Teile anders platziert, es sollte jetzt ohne Supports druckbar sein.

Habe nun auch ein paar Vorlagen für die Z-Achse erstellt und hochgeladen, bei der Halterung für die Spindel habe ich auf der Rückseite M6 Muttern mit einer Zange reingedrückt. Eventuell verbessere ich diese Vorlage noch ein wenig es ist ein früher Entwurf von jemandem der jetzt gerade erst Erfahrungen mit CNC macht, seid mir also bitte nicht böse wenn es nicht zu 100% euren Vorstellungen entspricht. Verbesserungsvorschläge werden dankend angenommen und sofern möglich umgesetzt.

title: Openbuilds OX Y axis limit switch bracket

description.text:
This is a limit switch bracket for my Openbuilds OX CNC. It can fit on V-Slots with two M5 screws and t-nuts. It holds firmly a Cherry Microswitch in place.

I had some 13mm acrylic leftover so I designed the bracket around this.

It can be 3D printed or milled on a CNC, like I did.

Infill:

100%

Notes:

When milling,

  1. mill the top side screw holes
  2. put screws in the holes into the spoilerboard.
  3. Mill the contour
  4. flip the part and screw it back in the same holes
  5. Mill the underside pockets.

Microswitch assembly:

  1. solder the wires to the switch
  2. press fit the switch in the slot puting the 2 leads in the larger space.

CNC assembly:

  1. insert 2 t-nuts in the V-Slots
  2. screw in with M5 10mm screws.
  3. connect the other side of the wires to the CNC board.

title: Small popup shade arm joint fixer

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8EY8bTbgwql

Small one is 8X16X70mm it was my first try at making one.
Big one is 10X17.5X70mm and fit perfectly with a little help into my 10x20 foot popup shade that had two broken arms.
If it works for you just leave a like. You can always import it into Tinkercad and change the size to fit your needs.
To make it even more solid just drill a poprivet hole towards both ends of the repair joint after the repair is installed then rivet each broken arm into the printed piece.

This is a simple part for the latch of a truck bed canopy handle. Scale should be such that length is 60.5 mm

Fits standard sized canopy latches (8.5 x 8.5 mm square hole), uses a 3 mm plastic screw to secure. 52 mm from the center of the square post to the tip of the latch, 15 mm from where the web ends to the end of the latch.

Not as strong as the steel catch that comes with the truck, but, the reality is neither will stop a motivated thief from getting in!

I used no support, 50% infill, and draft settings, printed with a little less than 3m of filament in about 20 minutes.

author: stinkytoad

title: Adafruit Joy Bonnet Docking 3.5" HDMI screen

description.text:
Announcement:

I launched a Kickstarter for one of my other projects, check it out here:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1096461972/6dof-electronic-interface-for-motion-simulator-pla

The new Joy Bonnet makes it very easy to convert the Raspberry Pi Zero W to a portable retro gaming pocket device. Well not so portable. You still need power and HDMI connection and a TV. In a few words still needs some cables attached on the device. Then, try playing for long time those low resolution Snes games on 65 inch TV screen... I mean looks good, but those huge pixels!

I like to have the Adafruit Joy Bonnet for playing on large TV screen to show off old games but not leave it hooked up there and perhaps use a smaller screen for it. I didn't want to modify anything so it would be easy to switch between the two. So... I designed a mini portable Docking Screen for it, that is battery powered.

The Docking Screen supports all HDMI resolutions so no need for modifications in the Config.txt for the resolution and has stereo audio via the HDMI cable. It provides the power to the Raspberry Pi Zero and breaks out the USB port for attaching external USB Joypad controller or USB hub.

The docking is done via normal mini USB cables and Mini HDMI adapter that are fixed on the front of the Docking screen. When it docks it kinda looks like a mini bar top arcade machine.

EDIT adding a one piece cover for protecting the Joy Bonnet. :)
EDIT2 Added screen cover to be glued on the front panel.

Video in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8kw8AQ4HKGQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R-IWIv_ZS6s

Also if you boot the screen before the raspberry you get much more clear and geometrically correct display. This can be done with two power switches, or simple reboot the Raspberry to get full HD HDMI resolution detected.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3PI04kHax0w

Parts used:
-Adafruit Joy Bonnet for Raspberry Pi: https://www.adafruit.com/product/3464
-Raspberry Pi Zero W: https://www.adafruit.com/product/3400
-Lithium Ion Battery Pack - 3.7V 4400mAh: https://www.adafruit.com/product/354
-Mini HDMI Plug to Standard HDMI Jack Adapter: https://www.adafruit.com/product/2819
-USB OTG Host Cable - MicroB OTG male to A female: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1099
-HDMI Female to Female Coupler
-3.5” HDMI Touch Screen LCD Display+clear case for Raspberry Pi 2 3 1080P:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/351953813537?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
-ESUMIC® L2go 3.5mm Mini Portable Stereo Speaker: http://www.ebay.com/itm/ESUMIC-L2go-3-5mm-Mini-Portable-Stereo-Speaker-for-iPod-iPhone-MP3-MP4-Pla-/142323776753?hash=item2123287cf1:g:dYcAAOSwol5Y1Fv1
-GERI Dual USB 5V 1A 2A Mobile Power Charger Power Board Module 3.7V to 5V Booster Converter with LCD Display:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B00VDP94QM/ref=mp_s_a_1_fkmr3_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1492897696&sr=8-1-fkmr3&pi=AC_SX236_SY340_QL65&keywords=SMAKN®+5V+2A+Dual+USB+LCD+all-in-one+Boost+Lithium

I removed the stereo speakers and amplifier from its case and connected them directly on the audio output of the HDMI screen and used double side tape to mount them on it. Also used a small switch to enable the power to the audio amplifier so I can turn off if needed. Audio level is set within Retropie. Other than that, look at the photos where all the parts are go, its very easy to put this together, with minimal soldering.

UPDATE* Fixed a little bit the dimensions and tolerances to reduce filing down for fit. This is Version 15 files.

Thanks
Thanos

Originally created by Schlotzz. It was easier for me to remodel it in Inventor than to modify the SCAD file. The original extruder is very nice but it was difficult somewhat to change the filament so I added a small handle for quick release and guided the filament as close to the drive gear and ball bearing as possible.

Print this model and tell me what you think, I have included the inventor files as well as STEP files for ease of modification. This is made for use with NEMA 17 stepper motors, 9 mm x 11 mm drive gear and 608ZZ bearing. This is for 1.75 mm filament.

Hardware needed:
3x 10 mm M3 screws with plain/lock washers
1x 15 mm M3 hex socket bolt
1x 20 mm M3 hex socket bolt with 2 plain washers
1x M3 nut
1x M3 nylock nut
1x 3mm ID spring
1 or 2 push-fit connectors 4mm tube OD M5
1x 8 mm M6 screw
2x M4 bolts

Tap the hole in the tensioner with an M6 tap, insert the bearing and screw it in place.
Insert the hex nut in the slot and tap the filament outlet (optional: and inlet) holes for M5 threads. Screw in the push-fit connectors and screw the body to the motor face with 3 screws in the counter bored holes. Attach the tensioner to the body with the 15 mm hex bolt but do not tighten as it will restrict the movement. With the tensioner closed, add the nylock nut to the 20 mm bolt backwards (you can do this by screwing it forwards until you tap the nylon and then flip it). Then add a washer, the spring, another washer and screw it through the slot of the tensioner till it screws in the previously inserted nut. Mount the extruder to your printer frame with the M4 screws.

Use the nylock nut to adjust the tension.
If you need another version for 624 bearing or another drive gear please let me know.

Future improvements might include PTFE filament guides.

title: Gear Lever Bushing for Ford Focus MK2.5

description.text:
My Ford Focus will not shift out of Park even when shift knob in Drive or Reverse. LCD display keeps blink with "P". The problem is a detached gear shift lever linkage due to worn bushing. Local shop only sell the whole transmission cable for around $140. Was reluctant to replace the whole thing just for a worn bushing, so I made it my 1st project and design one.

I wanted to print with Flexible TPU, but since this is an engine component, I'm worried for its heat resistance. Hence made one using ABS instead.

comments.text: Looks good, but a couple of questions.
comments.author: pinthenet99

comments.text: At last someone who does it right ! Although you should try to get the screw in  line with middle of the belt plane to avoid torsion as the housing may not be rigid enough to keep the part aligned. No need to put a nut, there are enough threads and  self tapping screw would be fine too. You don't adjust that often.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Hey, thank for you feedback. I added the "Filler_without_Nut" to the files so it's possible to use self tapping screws.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Fine if it works just that with the screw in line there is no way the adjustable part rotates sideways even with some less rigid plastic and high belt tension (I adjust to 13 N). I made a carriage that way and used a M2 screw to be as close as possible to the belt middle fibber.
In plastic, no problem to use even regular M screws provided you have more than 10 threads engaged. The parts are simpler and stronger as there is no hole for the nut. Just drill the hole as before tapping or even less. Threaded inserts are fine too in some cases. I reuse the ones scavenged from old laptops. The majority of what is published in Thingiverse uses too complex assembly using bolt and nuts, too many and too big making the parts even more fragile !. You don't see that in the industry but for special cases and with reinforcements (eg: good power drill)

description.text:
My own take on a Y-axis tensioner for Black Widow, didn't want to just make it look like a square industrial block, if you're already doing something - do it with style ;)

It uses already existing screws, pulley and washers that are used on BW, one item you will need is a single M6 screw (25mm~30mm) with a nut, slots for both are already incorporated into parts.

I have designed the screw holes a little tight, personally I'm using a drill to adjust the holes post printing on most occasions for a smooth tunnel, otherwise you may need a bit of force to drive the screws through.

Have a vision or two how to improve it a bit more, but it works as intended in its current state already.

Keep in mind the limits of your hardware!

The belt, held in many cases only by teeth facing each other pressed together by cable ties can and will slip out if pushed too far (it did for me on first try!), so that's your first limit to consider - and don't forget, on the other end you're applying this pressure directly to the shaft of the motor, so use common sense please.

Enjoy!

Printer:

TEVO Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.24

18%

Notes:

Printed with supports, face attaching to the printer flat on the bed, supports required for the mid section cut out

It's a tight fit between pulley attachment and the main body, may need a bit of sanding/filing to fit easier.

Screw holes designed tight, recommend using a drill to adjust them to correct size post printing.

The "Provisions" sign was obtained from a papercraft website on the link below. Just scale it down to 50% and print on some paper. Materials:
PLA, Compression Spring, double sided "poster" tape. See photos for how to install back plate and spring. If you properly size the hole around your spring no adhesive is needed to hold it in place. description.text:
I was asked if I could make the Lawbringer poleaxe from the For Honor video game by dylanwhopper on my Great Axe project. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2181579

Challenge accepted!

I've designed this to fit around a 1 foot 1" wooden dowel for all the top pieces and a 1 3/8" wooden dowel for the body. The length of the body is up to you but the in game model appears to be around 6 feet tall. You will have to adjust how the models are situated in your slicer of choice.

Print 2 copies of all the langet pieces and 6 copies of all the screws. The larger ones go on the axe head and the bottom langets. The smaller ones go on the top langets and the connector piece.

All the pieces should be glued together with either superglue or an epoxy.

EDIT 4/26/17 - I went a little overkill with the tolerances so now the cylinder pieces that touch the wood should fit much more snug. Also added A combined version of the butt pieces.

MP Select Mini

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

20%

Notes:

All of the larger pieces can be printed at .2mm resolution with no supports. (you can use them if you want)

The screws should be printed at the highest setting you can do as they are smaller pieces and detail is always nice.

comments.text:
Just another useless and detrimental to print quality item.
The threaded rods where not left loose by error but by design.
If the engineers wanted to restrict the wobbling of the threaded rods, all they had to do was to make the threaded rods 8 mm longer and make the hole in the acrylic/steel 8 mm in diam.
Think about a archers bow, if you restrict its ends and rotate it, the middle will wobble and in the printer's case, will excerpt pressure on the smooth rods in unpredictable ways, it will all depend on to where the wobbling in the middle of the threaded rod is going to.

I wanted a more positive connection of the wings to my mini drak so I developed these for 3mm nut and flat head screw (6mm long).

Be careful when gluing these in place you must make sure everything lines up properly. So let the glue cure with wings, spars and fins installed. Don't forget to put the hex nuts into the bases first!

I designed this with two screws instead of a male and female with one screw in the hopes that if anything breaks, it will be the bar piece and so replacing that would be simpler than having to carve out and reglue the base piece.

I recommend gluing the big fins to either the center fuse or the wings (not both obviously). This makes the fins stay rigid and vertical in high g manuevers. Otherwise it takes very little force to wiggle them around with any wing joining method (this one, velcro or the O rings) which could result in more wag.

title: Flsun i3 x/z axis 45 mm redesign
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've decided to make a version of my x/z-axis redesign with a center to center distance for the x-axis rods of 45 mm, with the belt centered. There have been many requests from certain people who want to use a prusa carriage with their flsun printer, so if you'd like to print an original prusa carriage with 45mm rod spacing and the belt centered, these are the brackets for your flsun i3!

For reference, this is the complete redesign with the original 70 mm spacing. Many people have reported success with this design alternative also.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2116748

As you know they are all random and too deep on the originals so if you tighten the belt it just pulls the carriage blocks closer together, so they have to be the right depth to keep the carriages aligned to their rods.  Trying to figure it out to improve mine.

title: [WIP] Laser Cut Maker Puzzle - Color mapped

description.text:
This is an alternative version of Jennifer Schachter's Laser Cut Maker Puzzle, built with Adam Savage for Tested.com's SXSW 2017 Scavenger Hunt. Details and original engraving/cutting/assembly tips at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2240542.

This is VERY MUCH a work in progress aiming to make the puzzle easier to engrave and cut on the laser cutter at the Johnson County Library MakerSpace, or any laser cutter that can process color-mapped designs.

I've tested some of the files on our laser cutters with chipboard and so far everything looks good! I'll keep testing the designs and let you know what I find - but you do your testing know and let me know how it turns out for you!

I used the following color-mapping settings:

  • raster engrave (blue) - Speed 100 Power 50 Frequency 500
  • vector engrave (green) - Speed 100 Power 3 Frequency 500
  • vector cut (red) - Speed 100 Power 70 Frequency 500

04/28/2017
It's time for another round of files!

  • all vector engrave lines and cutting lines resized to 0.001" lines for hairlines in Corel Draw
  • added .emf files for importing into Corel Draw

04/23/2017

  • distributed each layer of the puzzle pieces on separate layers
  • switched to vector engraves where relevant
